metadata.description: 1) Data content: species list and distribution data of Phrynocephalus and Eremais in Tarim Basin, including class, order, family, genus, species, and detailed distribution information including country, province, city and county; 2) Data source and processing method: Based on the field survey of amphibians and reptiles in Tarim Basin from 2008 to 2020, and recording the species composition and distribution range of Phrynocephalus and Eremias in this area; 3) Data quality description: the investigation, collection and identification of samples are all conducted by professionals, and the collection of samples information are checked to ensure the quality of distribution data; 4) Data application results and prospects: Through comprehensive analysis of the dataset, the list of species diversity and distribution can provide important data for biodiversity cataloguing in arid central Asia, and provide scientific basis for assessing biodiversity pattern and formulating conservation strategies.

background: There are about 1,200 lakes (>1 km2) on the Tibetan Plateau (TP; Zhang, Yao, Xie, Qin, et al., 2014), and many studies have shown that lake ice phenology (i.e., the timing of freezeup, breakup, and duration of ice cover) responds well to climatic and environmental changes (Brown & Duguay, 2010; Weber et al., 2016). As “the Third Pole of the Earth,” the TP is very sensitive to global climate change (Kang et al., 2010; Liu & Chen, 2000; Qiu, 2008). Changes in air and water surface temperatures related to climatic changes are important factors in the lake ice phenology changes (Adrian et al., 2009; Dörnhöfer & Oppelt, 2016; Yao et al., 2016; Zhang, Yao, Xie, Zhang, et al., 2014). At the same time, the state and type of lake ice and their change to open water system in turn affect the local or regional climate (Brown & Duguay, 2010; Rouse et al., 2005). However, due to the harsh environment and limited accessibility, few meteorological stations exist in the central and western TP where lakes are concentrated; thus, it is difficult to carry out field observations. The unique geographical and climatic conditions of the TP make it a region of high interest for climate research (Kang et al., 2010).
research objective: To obtain the lake ice phenology variations on the TP, the daily snow products of MODIS are used to extract the freezeup and breakup dates of lake‐wide ice cover from 2001 to 2017. In addition, possible influence of geographical determined lake locations and physico‐chemical conditions on lake ice phenology are also investigated.
challenges: However, due to the harsh environment and limited accessibility, few meteorological stations exist in the central and western TP where lakes are concentrated; thus, it is difficult to carry out field observations. These factors result in a lack of continuous and complete historical records on regional climate changes.
methods: By analyzing the freezeup/breakup characteristics for each lake on the TP, 58 lakes with a stable ice cover period (less cloud cover, less pixel misclassification, and obvious ice cover period) are manually selected as study lakes. The data were obtained from the U.S. National Snow and Ice Data Center (http://nsidc.org/; version 5 for 2001–2016 and version 6 for 2017) on 8 September 2017. To extract lake ice, pixels covering a lake need to be first distinguished from other types of pixels, such as cloud and land. A threshold of 0.4 for Normalized Difference Snow Index (NDSI; Hall et al., 2001) is applied to extract the extent of a lake. The cloud removal (gapfilling) process has two steps. The first step is to combine daily Terra and Aqua snow cover products to determine lake cover type. The second step is based on the temporal correlation of cloud cover pixels. First, if a pixel on date t is cloud covered, the pixels on the images of previous and next days will be searched, and if both pixels are covered by water, pixel on date t is determined to be covered by water.
dataset: The available daily snow cover products with a spatial resolution of 500 m from MODIS include MOD10A1 (Terra) and MYD10A1 (Aqua). The available temporal range of MOD10A1 is from 1 August 2000 to 31 July 2017 and that of MYD10A1 is from 1 August 2002 to 31 July 2017. Four MODIS tiles (h24v05, h25v05, h25v06, and h26v05) cover the 58 lakes of this study. The Landsat program is a series of Earth observing satellites, which is comanaged by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the United States Geological Survey to monitor Earth and environmental resources. Since 23 July 1972, eight satellites have been launched including Landsat Multispectral Scanner (MSS; ~80 m) and Thematic Mapper (TM; 30 m)/Enhanced Thematic Mapper Plus (ETM+; 30 m)/Operational Land Imager (OLI; 30 m) with a temporal resolution of 16 days.
findings: Over 17 years, the mean ice cover duration of 58 lakes is 157.78 days, 18 (31%) lakes have a mean extending rate of 1.11 day/year, and 40 (69%) lakes have a mean shortening rate of 0.80 day/year.

Definition.Question: What does 'lake ice phenology' refer to in the context of climate studies on the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: Lake ice phenology refers to the study of seasonal ice cover changes on lakes, including the timing of freeze-up and break-up, as well as the duration of ice cover. It is an important indicator of climatic and environmental changes, particularly on the Tibetan Plateau where these dynamics are sensitive to global climate change.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in collecting continuous and complete historical records of regional climate changes, and how might these challenges affect data interpretation?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges in collecting continuous and complete historical records of regional climate changes include harsh environmental conditions and limited accessibility, especially in areas with few meteorological stations like the central and western Tibetan Plateau. These factors can lead to gaps in data, making it difficult to interpret long-term climate trends accurately.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the impact of geographical and physico-chemical conditions on lake ice phenology from the use of MODIS daily snow products in data collection?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of MODIS daily snow products allows for the extraction of lake ice phenology variations by analyzing freezeup and breakup dates of lake-wide ice cover. This approach helps infer that geographical location and physico-chemical conditions significantly influence lake ice phenology, as these factors determine the timing and duration of ice cover, as well as the response of lakes to climatic changes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in collecting continuous and complete historical records for regional climate changes in areas like the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Factors such as the harsh environment, limited accessibility, and the scarcity of meteorological stations in the central and western Tibetan Plateau where lakes are concentrated contribute to the challenges in collecting continuous and complete historical records for regional climate changes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it difficult to carry out field observations in the central and western Tibetan Plateau, and how do these difficulties influence data collection methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The difficulty in carrying out field observations in the central and western Tibetan Plateau is due to the harsh environment and limited accessibility. These challenges necessitate the use of remote sensing data, such as MODIS snow cover products, to study lake ice phenology in the region.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the lack of continuous and complete historical records on regional climate changes influence the reliability of the data collected from the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The lack of continuous and complete historical records on regional climate changes due to limited accessibility and harsh environmental conditions in the central and western Tibetan Plateau can lead to gaps in data, affecting the reliability of field observations and long-term climate trend analyses. This makes it challenging to establish accurate baselines and assess changes over time.

Causal Consequence.Question: What impact does the application of a threshold for Normalized Difference Snow Index (NDSI) have on the extraction of lake ice cover data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Applying a threshold of 0.4 for the Normalized Difference Snow Index (NDSI) helps distinguish lake ice from cloud and land pixels, facilitating the extraction of lake ice cover data. This method enhances the accuracy of detecting ice extent, although it relies on the assumption that the threshold effectively discriminates between these surface types, which may not always be the case in complex or mixed conditions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals behind manually selecting lakes with stable ice cover periods for research on the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to accurately identify freezeup and breakup characteristics by focusing on lakes with minimal cloud cover and pixel misclassification. This selection ensures reliable data extraction and analysis, enabling researchers to study the effects of climate change on lake ice phenology more effectively.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the geographical and climatic conditions of a region influence the data collection process for lake ice phenology?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The unique geographical and climatic conditions, such as those on the Tibetan Plateau, make it a region of high interest for climate research. However, the harsh environment and limited accessibility mean that few meteorological stations exist, making it difficult to carry out field observations and resulting in a lack of continuous and complete historical records on regional climate changes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in extracting lake ice phenology data from satellite imagery?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To extract lake ice phenology, daily snow products of MODIS are used. The procedure involves selecting lakes with stable ice cover periods, identifying lake pixels using a threshold for Normalized Difference Snow Index (NDSI), and applying a cloud removal process. This process includes combining daily Terra and Aqua snow cover products and using temporal correlations of cloud cover pixels to determine lake cover type.

Enablement.Question: How do geographical conditions influence the ability to conduct field observations for lake ice phenology on the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: Geographical conditions such as the harsh environment and limited accessibility in the central and western Tibetan Plateau, where lakes are concentrated, make it difficult to carry out field observations, resulting in a lack of continuous and complete historical records on regional climate changes.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or methodologies enable the extraction of accurate lake ice phenology data from remote sensing sources?
Enablement.Answer: The application of a threshold of 0.4 for Normalized Difference Snow Index (NDSI) and a cloud removal process that combines daily Terra and Aqua snow cover products and leverages the temporal correlation of cloud cover pixels enable the extraction of accurate lake ice phenology data from MODIS remote sensing products.

Expectation.Question: Why are the meteorological conditions in the Tibetan Plateau expected to challenge traditional data collection methods for lake ice phenology?
Expectation.Answer: The harsh environment and limited accessibility in the Tibetan Plateau, where few meteorological stations exist, make it difficult to carry out field observations, resulting in challenges for continuous data collection on lake ice phenology.

Expectation.Question: Why might integrating MODIS snow cover products with other satellite data improve the understanding of lake ice phenology?
Expectation.Answer: Integrating MODIS snow cover products with other satellite data, like Landsat, can improve understanding because MODIS provides daily observations and a broad spatial coverage, while Landsat offers higher spatial resolution, complementing each other to fill data gaps and enhance the accuracy of lake ice phenology assessments.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the effectiveness of using MODIS daily snow products for extracting lake ice phenology in terms of data accuracy and methodological rigor?
